> Hi Jeff, congrats on this excellent work. That's great that IEEE picked i=
t up so fast, but I'm not surprised they like it. All the attention shows t=
here's something intuitively appealing that feels natural about this domain=
. Maybe it could also succeed on Slashdot.
> 
> 
Thanks Ken. Since the IEEE=
 post, the video has gone viral (ish). NBC did a story on it (http://goo.gl=
/OJldm) and it was on the front page of BuzzFeed, reddit/r/science, and eve=
n Youtube's "most popular videos" page. So far it's received 68,500 views i=
n around 48 hours. It's been fun to watch people get so excited about this =
sort of work. 

It would be great if it got Slashdotted. I have been hoping=
 it might happen on its own, but if it doesn't we may try to submit somethi=
ng early next week. 

> I also wanted to make a slightly more controversial=
 point of praise, which I hope you don't mind, but one of my favorite parts=
 of the paper is this:
> 
> "Because it is notoriously difficult to quantif=
y attributes
> such as "impressiveness" and "complexity", we make no effort=

> to do so here. Instead, we attempt to visually represent
> the interesti=
ng diversity of morphologies and behaviors that
> evolved once evolution wa=
s provided with more materials
> and a sophisticated encoding."
> 
> I real=
ly appreciated the open acknowledgment of the potential pretense of these k=
inds of measures. Given the recognition this paper is already receiving, it=
's nice to see that sometimes people can agree that something is interestin=
g simply by looking at it rather than through a mysterious quantification t=
hat no one really understands. (Although of course that doesn't mean measur=
ing something is always bad either, but it does tend to be overemphasized i=
n many cases.)
> 
Thanks. I agree. But, as you've said many times, reviewer=
s don't like evaluating subjective things on their own, and they lean on p-=
values and demand meaningless quantitative comparisons because they are unc=
omfortable not having an excuse to accept/reject a paper. I love quantitati=
ve measures and p-values when they help, but I think it is unfortunate that=
 many reviewers think that they are *necessary* for publication. 

I actual=
ly submitted another paper to GECCO that was rejected that was similar to t=
his work in that it showed interesting visual results, but did not attempt =
to force a quantification or experimental comparison that would have been u=
ninformative. The response? A rejection, with comments like this one:

"The=
 paper is grammatically well written, and organized. There are many illustr=
ations showing the a variety of evolved results. They all look very impress=
ive, and the system certainly seems to have promise.

Unfortunately, there =
is absolutely no empirical analysis included in the paper to support this r=
esearch. Therefore, this paper is not suitable for academic publication in =
its current form. A scientifically rigorous analysis must be given, which i=
s expected for all scientific papers in evolutionary computation, and GECCO=
 in particular. Issues that must be addressed include: evolutionary perform=
ance; statistical likelihood of solution quality; effects of experimental p=
arameters; effects of target models; etc."

When I read that I thought: "Th=
is is exactly what Ken has been complaining about!" It's everything you've =
been saying about reviewers distilled into one comment. They like the ideas=
 and results, and thought the technical advance was impressive and new, but=
 because I didn't present numbers and p-values they rejected it. Apparently=
 if I had fiddled with the parameters a bit and showed them plots and p-vla=
ues=85which would not have shed any light on the main innovation of the pap=
er=85then they would have had an excuse to accept the paper. I was shocked =
to see this view expressed so explicitly!


-Jeff


> 
> Best,
> 
> ken 
> =

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hell=
o all,
> > 
> > I am pleased to announce a new paper on evolving soft robot=
s with CPPNs. In it we try to improve the complexity of evolved virtual org=
anisms over what Karl Sims generated nearly 20 years ago. What do you think=
: are we on track to do that? Have we already? The video is the best way to=
 judge.
> > 
> > ----------Unplanned Last Minute Upate --------------
> > I=
 just found out that the video for the paper is on the front page of Hacker=
 News (I have no idea how they found it so fast without any announcements).=
 
> > 
> > If you want to help out, please go here and "up vote" us. You'll=
 need to register, but that is painless. NOTE: you may have to scroll to th=
e second or third page (hopefully not!).
> > 
> > https://news.ycombinator.=
com/news
> > 
> > Look for: "Bizarre Soft Robots Evolve to Run (ieee.org)"
=
> > ----------------------------------------------------------
> > 
> > Cit=
e: Cheney N, MacCurdy R, Clune J, Lipson H (2013) Unshackling evolution: ev=
olving soft robots with multiple materials and a powerful generative encodi=
ng. Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference. 
> =
> 
> > Video: http://youtu.be/z9ptOeByLA4
> > 
> > PDF: http://jeffclune.co=
m/publications/2013_Softbots_GECCO.pdf
> > 
> > Abstract: In 1994 Karl Sims=
 showed that computational evolution can produce interesting morphologies t=
hat resemble natural organisms. Despite nearly two decades of work since, e=
volved morphologies are not obviously more complex or natural, and the fiel=
d seems to have hit a complexity ceiling. One hypothesis for the lack of in=
creased complexity is that most work, including Sims', evolves morphologies=
 composed of rigid elements, such as solid cubes and cylinders, limiting th=
e design space. A second hypothesis is that the encodings of previous work =
have been overly regular, not allowing complex regularities with variation.=
 Here we test both hypotheses by evolving soft robots with multiple materia=
ls and a powerful generative encoding called a compositional pattern-produc=
ing network (CPPN). Robots are selected for locomotion speed. We find that =
CPPNs evolve faster robots than a direct encoding and that the CPPN morphol=
ogies appear more natural. We also find that locomotion performance increas=
es as more materials are added, that diversity of form and behavior can be =
increased with different cost functions without stifling performance, and t=
hat organisms can be evolved at different levels of resolution. These findi=
ngs suggest the ability of generative soft-voxel systems to scale towards e=
volving a large diversity of complex, natural, multi-material creatures. Ou=
r results suggest that future work that combines the evolution of CPPN-enco=
ded soft, multi-material robots with modern diversity-encouraging technique=
s could finally enable the creation of creatures far more complex and inter=
esting than those produced by Sims nearly twenty years ago.
> > 
> > As alw=
ays, please let me know if you have any comments or questions!
> > 
> > PS.=
 Here is the IEEE Spectrum article that found the video: http://spectrum.ie=
ee.org/automaton/robotics/robotics-software/bizarre-soft-robots-evolve-to-r=
un
> > 
> > 
> > Best regards,
> > Jeff Clune
> > 
> > Assistant Professor
=
> > Computer Science
> > University of Wyoming
> > jeffclune@...
> > jeffcl=
une.com
> >
> 
>

ote><div>Thanks Ken. Since the IEEE post, the video has gone viral (ish). N=

ound 48 hours. It's been fun to watch people get so excited about this sort=

otted. I have been hoping it might happen on its own, but if it doesn't we =
may try to submit something early next week. </div><div><br></div><blo=
ckquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); p=
osition: static; z-index: auto; "><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:=
relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"=
><p>
I also wanted to make a slightly more controversial point of praise, w=
hich I hope you don't mind, but one of my favorite parts of the paper is th=
is:<br>
<br>
"Because it is notoriously difficult to quantify attributes<br=
>
such as "impressiveness" and "complexity", we make no effort<br>
to do so=
 here. Instead, we attempt to visually represent<br>
the interesting divers=
ity of morphologies and behaviors that<br>
evolved once evolution was provi=
ded with more materials<br>
and a sophisticated encoding."<br>
<br>
I reall=
y appreciated the open acknowledgment of the potential pretense of these ki=
nds of measures.  Given the recognition this paper is already receiving, it=
's nice to see that sometimes people can agree that something is interestin=
g simply by looking at it rather than through a mysterious quantification t=
hat no one really understands. (Although of course that doesn't mean measur=
ing something is always bad either, but it does tend to be overemphasized i=
n many cases.)<br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>Thanks. I a=
gree. But, as you've said many times, reviewers don't like evaluating subje=
ctive things on their own, and they lean on p-values and demand meaningless=
 quantitative comparisons because they are uncomfortable not having an excu=
se to accept/reject a paper. I love quantitative measures and p-values when=
 they help, but I think it is unfortunate that many reviewers think that th=
ey are *necessary* for publication. </div><div><br></div><div>I actual=
ly submitted another paper to GECCO that was rejected that was similar to t=
his work in that it showed interesting visual results, but did not attempt =
to force a quantification or experimental comparison that would have been u=
ninformative. The response? A rejection, with comments like this one:</div>=
<div><br></div><div>"The paper is grammatically well written, and organized=
. There are many illustrations showing the a variety of evolved result=
s. They all look very impressive, and the system certainly seems to have pr=
omise.</div><br>Unfortunately, there is absolutely no empirical analysis in=
cluded in the paper to support this research. Therefore, this paper is=
 not suitable for academic publication in its current form. A scientificall=
y rigorous analysis must be given, which is expected for all scie=
ntific papers in evolutionary computation, and GECCO in particular. Issues =
that must be addressed include: evolutionary performance; statistical =
likelihood of solution quality; effects of experimental parameters; ef=
fects of target models; etc."</div><div><br></div><div>When I read tha=
t I thought: "This is exactly what Ken has been complaining about!" It's ev=
erything you've been saying about reviewers distilled into one comment. The=
y like the ideas and results, and thought the technical advance was impress=
ive and new, but because I didn't present numbers and p-values they rejecte=
d it. Apparently if I had fiddled with the parameters a bit and showed them=
 plots and p-vlaues=85which would not have shed any light on the main innov=
ation of the paper=85then they would have had an excuse to accept the paper=
. I was shocked to see this view expressed so explicitly!</div><div><br></d=
iv><div><br></div><div>-Jeff<br><div><br></div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite=
"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-i=
ndex: auto; "><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=
=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>

ft Robots Evolve to Run (<a href=3D"http://ieee.org">ieee.org</a>)"<br>
&gt=

=
> Cite: Cheney N, MacCurdy R, Clune J, Lipson H (2013) Unshackling evolu=
tion: evolving soft robots with multiple materials and a powerful generativ=
e encoding. Proceedings of the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Confere=
nce. <br>
> <br>
> Video: <a href=3D"http://youtu.be/z9ptOeByLA4">htt=
p://youtu.be/z9ptOeByLA4</a><br>
> <br>
> PDF: <a href=3D"http://jeff=
clune.com/publications/2013_Softbots_GECCO.pdf">http://jeffclune.com/public=
ations/2013_Softbots_GECCO.pdf</a><br>
> <br>
> Abstract: In 1994 Kar=
l Sims showed that computational evolution can produce interesting morpholo=
gies that resemble natural organisms. Despite nearly two decades of work si=
nce, evolved morphologies are not obviously more complex or natural, and th=
e field seems to have hit a complexity ceiling. One hypothesis for the lack=
 of increased complexity is that most work, including Sims', evolves morpho=
logies composed of rigid elements, such as solid cubes and cylinders, limit=
ing the design space. A second hypothesis is that the encodings of previous=
 work have been overly regular, not allowing complex regularities with vari=
ation. Here we test both hypotheses by evolving soft robots with multiple m=
aterials and a powerful generative encoding called a compositional pattern-=
producing network (CPPN). Robots are selected for locomotion speed. We find=
 that CPPNs evolve faster robots than a direct encoding and that the CPPN m=
orphologies appear more natural. We also find that locomotion performance i=
ncreases as more materials are added, that diversity of form and behavior c=
an be increased with different cost functions without stifling performance,=
 and that organisms can be evolved at different levels of resolution.  Thes=
e findings suggest the ability of generative soft-voxel systems to scale to=
wards evolving a large diversity of complex, natural, multi-material creatu=
res. Our results suggest that future work that combines the evolution of CP=
PN-encoded soft, multi-material robots with modern diversity-encouraging te=
chniques could finally enable the creation of creatures far more complex an=
d interesting than those produced by Sims nearly twenty years ago.<br>
>=
 <br>
> As always, please let me know if you have any comments or questi=
ons!<br>
> <br>

e video: <a href=3D"http://spectrum.ieee.org/automaton/robotics/robotics-so=
ftware/bizarre-soft-robots-evolve-to-run">http://spectrum.ieee.org/automato=
n/robotics/robotics-software/bizarre-soft-robots-evolve-to-run</a><br>
>=
